content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure shows a 2 row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in days,” and the heading for row 2 is “r prime of t, in centimeters per day.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0; r prime of t is negative 6.1. Column 2. t is 3; r prime of t is negative 5.0. Column 3. t is 7; r prime of t is negative 4.4. Column 4. t is 10; r prime of t is negative 3.8. Column 5. t is 12; r prime of t is negative 3.5." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable columnlines="solid solid solid solid solid none" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid none"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(days)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><msup><mi>r</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(centimeters per day)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mo>-</mo><mn>6.1</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>-</mo><mn>5.0</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>-</mo><mn>4.4</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>-</mo><mn>3.8</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>-</mo><mn>3.5</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math> An ice sculpture melts in such a way that it can be modeled as a cone that maintains a conical shape as it decreases in size. The radius of the base of the cone is given by a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="r of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in centimeters and <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in days. The table shown gives selected values of <math alttext="r prime of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the rate of change of the radius, over the time interval <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Approximate <math alttext="r double prime of 8.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>r</mi><mo>″</mo></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>8.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> using the average rate of change of <math alttext="r prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> over the interval <math alttext="7 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer, and indicate units of measure.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure shows a 2 row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in days,” and the heading for row 2 is “r prime of t, in centimeters per day.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0; r prime of t is negative 6.1. Column 2. t is 3; r prime of t is negative 5.0. Column 3. t is 7; r prime of t is negative 4.4. Column 4. t is 10; r prime of t is negative 3.8. Column 5. t is 12; r prime of t is negative 3.5." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable columnlines="solid solid solid solid solid none" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid none"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(days)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><msup><mi>r</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(centimeters per day)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mo>-</mo><mn>6.1</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>-</mo><mn>5.0</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>-</mo><mn>4.4</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>-</mo><mn>3.8</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>-</mo><mn>3.5</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math> An ice sculpture melts in such a way that it can be modeled as a cone that maintains a conical shape as it decreases in size. The radius of the base of the cone is given by a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="r of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in centimeters and <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in days. The table shown gives selected values of <math alttext="r prime of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the rate of change of the radius, over the time interval <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Approximate <math alttext="r double prime of 8.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>r</mi><mo>″</mo></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>8.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> using the average rate of change of <math alttext="r prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> over the interval <math alttext="7 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer, and indicate units of measure.

(b) Is there a time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, for which <math alttext="r prime of t equals negative 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

(c) Use a right Riemann sum with the four subintervals indicated in the table to approximate the value of <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 12, of, r prime of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) The height of the cone decreases at a rate of <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> centimeters per day. At time <math alttext="t equals 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> days, the radius is <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn></math> centimeters and the height is <math alttext="50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> centimeters. Find the rate of change of the volume of the cone with respect to time, in cubic centimeters per day, at time <math alttext="t equals 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> days. (The volume <math alttext="V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of a cone with radius <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and height <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="V equals one third pi, times r squared, times h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>π</mi><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.)

topic.text: 1.16: Working with the Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Identify mathematical information from graphical, numerical, analytical, and/or verbal representations.
